posts.title: The unmarked ramen window behind Jade Market
posts.content: Only open Thursday nights after 9pm. Look for the red lantern in the alley - cash only, no photos. The owner makes exactly 50 bowls using his grandmother's recipe from Fukuoka. Best tonkotsu I've had outside Japan.

posts.title: Abuela's cart - she remembers your order after two visits
posts.content: Behind the auto parts store on 82nd. Maria only makes what she feels like that day, but if you're lucky enough to catch her mole negro, you'll understand why people text each other when she's there. She'll remember your name and order after your second visit.

posts.title: The Sunday supper club in an artist's backyard
posts.content: Every other Sunday, Kai transforms their backyard studio into a 12-seat dining room. Plant-based tasting menu changes with what's growing in their garden. Text the number on the mural at Alberta & 15th for the next date. Sliding scale $20-60.

posts.title: The garage where they roast coffee at dawn
posts.content: Sam roasts beans in their garage every Tuesday at 5am - neighbors wake up to the smell. Knock three times if the garage door is down. They'll sell you a bag still warm from the roaster, and probably tell you about the farm in Guatemala where they stayed last winter.

posts.title: Monthly forager dinners at the edge of Forest Park
posts.content: Jesse leads foraging walks that end at their cabin for a meal made from what we found. Chanterelles, nettles, wild ginger - depending on season. Limited to 8 people, you have to have attended one of their plant ID workshops first. Worth it for the pine tip ice cream alone.

posts.title: The basement where noise bands play on Wednesdays
posts.content: Look for the house with the purple door near Hawthorne. $5-10 sliding scale at the door goes directly to touring bands. BYOB, bring earplugs. The washing machine might run during sets. Some of the best experimental music I've heard has been in that unfinished basement.

posts.title: The guerrilla garden spots we've been tending
posts.content: Those tomatoes by the bus stop on Division? We planted those. The herb spiral behind the abandoned lot on 28th? Also us. Meet Sunday mornings at 7am at the tool library if you want to help. We're slowly making the neighborhood more edible.

posts.title: Dawn walks through the industrial eastside
posts.content: Meet at the steel bridge at 5:30am Saturdays. We walk the industrial district as the city wakes up - best light, no crowds. The guy who runs the scrapyard lets us shoot in his lot if we bring him coffee. Some of my favorite portraits have been of workers starting their shifts.

posts.title: The fence where we leave warm clothes
posts.content: Southeast corner of Laurelhurst Park. If you have extra coats, blankets, or sleeping bags, zip-tie them to the fence. They never last more than a few hours - someone always needs them. Started with one jacket last winter, now neighbors maintain it daily.

posts.title: The seed library in the bookstore basement
posts.content: Down the narrow stairs at the back of the used bookstore on Mississippi. Take seeds, leave seeds. The librarian has been saving heirloom varieties for 30 years - ask about the Cherokee purple tomatoes that grow despite our rain. They'll talk your ear off, but you'll leave with seeds that actually work here.

posts.title: Poetry nights in rotating living rooms
posts.content: Text 'VERSE' to the number on the Powell's bathroom stall (3rd floor, poetry section). Each month it's someone else's living room, max 20 people. Last time a 70-year-old read about their transition and we all cried. Bring a poem or just listen. Tea provided, feelings inevitable.

posts.title: The Mt. Tabor stairs crew that meets before sunrise
posts.content: Every morning at 5:45am, rain or shine. No names, no small talk, just head nods and heavy breathing. We run the stairs until someone pukes or the sun comes up. Been going for three years. You'll know us by the headlamps and the fact that we're the only idiots out there.

posts.title: The neighborhood cats and their people
posts.content: Orange tabby by the blue house is Mango (not lost, just social). Black cat on 39th is Shadow (deaf, don't sneak up). Tortie who screams at everyone is Princess (she's fine, just dramatic). We have a group text for when someone looks actually lost. Join us - cats know the real neighborhood boundaries.

posts.title: The garage with 500 board games you can borrow
posts.content: Red garage door on Woodstock with the dragon mural. Knock if it's closed - they're usually in the workshop behind. Take a game, leave a game, or just borrow. They have everything from 1970s Avalon Hill to last week's Kickstarter. The couple who runs it will teach you any game if you have time.

posts.title: Building cob ovens in backyards all summer
posts.content: We've built 12 so far. If you have space and can gather 20 friends for a weekend, we'll help you build one. You provide pizza afterwards for life. The one on 42nd has Friday pizza nights, the Alberta one does Sunday bagels. Creating neighborhood gathering spots, one oven at a time.

posts.title: The intersection repair crew that works at night
posts.content: We painted that mandala at 20th and Clinton at 3am with headlamps. The city keeps painting over our crosswalk art, we keep coming back. Next target is the dangerous crossing at 82nd and Foster. Meet at the 24-hour donut shop if you want in. Bring reflective gear.

posts.title: Playing the bridges at dawn
posts.content: Steel Bridge hums at E flat, Tilikum resonates at B. We meet first Sunday of each month at sunrise with contact mics and portable amps. Last month a MAX driver stopped to listen. The bridges are instruments if you know how to play them. Bring a recorder if you want to sample.

posts.title: The fermentation phone tree
posts.content: When someone's kraut is ready, they text three people. Those people text three more. Within hours, dozens show up with jars. Last week's gathering had 47 different ferments - someone brought 3-year aged miso. We trade starters like they're precious gems. My kitchen hasn't been without bubbling jars since I joined.

posts.title: The warehouse where beautiful trash becomes art
posts.content: Old loading dock off Columbia. Ring the bell that says 'deliveries.' Inside: thousands of sorted materials - bottle caps by color, circuit boards by era, broken glass by hue. Take what you need, leave what you find. The person who runs it has been collecting for 20 years. They remember every piece.

posts.title: Walking group for people with anxiety
posts.content: Laurelhurst Park, Tuesdays 6pm by the duck pond. No talking required - we just walk. Some people have been coming for years and never said a word. That's fine. Sometimes just being around others who get it is enough. Dogs welcome, they help.

posts.title: The crow feeding route and what they remember
posts.content: Start at Irving Park with unsalted peanuts. The crows know me now - they follow my bike and tell their friends. One brings bottle caps as trade. They remember faces for years, pass grudges to their children. Be consistent, be kind. They'll show you where they roost at sunset.
